title: What are the trends in publicly funded adult social care staff numbers?
analysis_commentary:
Here we look at data on staff (directly and indirectly) employed by adult social services departments in England only. The data does not include information on privately funded social care, or children's social services. For more information on this data please see 'about this data' below.

For professional staff (which include social workers, occupational therapists, registered nurses and allied health professionals), the percentage change increases by 3% from 2011 to 2013 but then decreases in 2014 by 2%. They were the smallest group from 2011 to 2013 but in 2014 the managers, supervisors group became the smallest. This group decreased in size by 22% from 2011 to 2014. The other two groups have also decreased: other staff (which includes roles not directly involved in providing care and support, such as HR and IT) by 19%; and direct care (which includes all roles which provide care or support directly, such as care workers and support workers) decreased by 27% in three years.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Personal Social Services: Staff of Social Services Departments
